description: On March 16, the Finnish Government's Ministry of education and culture has adopted policy recommendations for the education sector. "Early childhood education and care units and the pre-primary education associated will be kept in operation. However, the Government recommends children being cared for at home."For primary and lower secondary education, school premises will be closed until 13 April 2020 and contact teaching will be suspended. As an exception, pre-primary education organised in schools and contact teaching for pupils in grades 1 to 3 will continue for the children of parents who work in sectors critical to the functioning of society. The premises of schools, educational institutions, universities, universities of applied sciences, basic art education as well as civic education and other liberal education institutes will be closed until 13 April 2020, and contact teaching will be suspended. Teaching and guidance will be organised as widely as possible in alternative ways, including distance learning. All national and municipal museums, theatres, the National Opera, cultural venues, libraries, mobile libraries, services for customer and researchers at the National Archives, hobby and leisure centres, swimming pools and other sports facilities, youth centres, clubs, organisations’ meeting rooms, day care services for the elderly, rehabilitative work facilities and workshops will be closed until 13 April. These arrangements were entered into force on Wednesday 18 March 2020. On March 31, the exceptional arrangements for education were announced to be extended until 13 May, and considering the situations of the pandemic, possibly to the end of the term.

The school year is set to end on 30 May.

On 29 May, the Finnish government announces the reopening of domestic tourism and set in a number of specific guidelines to be followed. This includes:
- sick persons should avoid all travel
- symptoms must be reported immediately to healthcare services of the municipality or city where you are staying
- if a domestic tourist becomes infected with the coronavirus,the physician responsible for diseases in the municipality or hospital district is responsible for tracing the infection

On 19 May, the Finnish government decides to lay down provisions on restrictions for restaurants:
- the number of seats in restaurants, cafes, and bars would be reduced in order for customers to maintain a sufficient distance between one another
- customers must be provided with instructions on how to avoid contracting the virus
-  food and beverage service providers must make sure to adequately clean all surfaces and objects that customers touch
- customers are not allowed to serve or dish out their own food or drinks, for example, at a buffet table
- food and beverage service businesses are allowed to be open to customers between 06:00-23:00
- alcohol may served only between 09:00 - 22:00; if a customer buys an alcoholic beverage before 22:00, then it must be consumed by 23:00
- food and beverage services must draw up a plan on how to implement these regulations

The Finnish government announces on 17 June that it will ease restrictions on food and beverage services, beginning on 22 June. The following restrictions have been changed:
- businesses may open at 04:00 and must close by 02:00
- buffets are once again permitted
- three-quarters of the number of persons permitted in the serving license or building plan may be present in the indoor premises at one time

All customers are still required to have their own seat and businesses must arrange their indoor and outdoor furniture to maintain a safe distance between one another. description:
On May 15, Finland's Ministry of Social Affairs and Health announces that restrictions on mass gatherings will be eased, beginning on 1 June. The restriction of public gatherings will be eased from the current 10 persons to a maximum of 50 people. Public events with more than 50 people indoor and enclosed outdoor spaces will also be allowed, provided that every person can keep a safe distance of 1-2 meters from other people. Events with more than 500 attendees in enclosed outdoor spaces will remain prohibited until 31 July. On June 11, the Finnish government updates its policy on outdoor events and say that the permitted number of attendees may exceed 500 persons if:
- event attendees can be placed in their own seating areas of viewing sections, each of which has a maximum capacity of 500 persons, with the ability to maintain safe distance and by providing hygiene instructions
- a clear buffer zone is arranged between each viewing section, have its own access routes, services (food/beverage/sanitary), event staff
 UPDATE: On 11 June, the Finnish government releases specifications to its policy regarding public events.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description:
On June 17, the Finnish government announces the removal of the restriction that barred visits to hospitals and primary healthcare units. The government says that a cautious approach must be taken when arranging visits and that the operating unit is in charge of making practical arrangements, such as the use of PPEs and appropriate meeting places.

Units providing 24-hour care and treatment must provide their older clients and others belonging to risk groups with the opportunity to meet their loved ones safely, by ensuring adequate protection in an outdoor location or by arranging separate, protected, meeting facilities.

As a general rule, the government recommends that access to premises providing 24-hour care and treatment remain limited to staff.
